title: Blockchain Data Fundamentals
description:
The purpose of this topic is to test and deepen students' basic understanding of blockchain technology, the Ethereum platform, and smart contracts.
Content will cover basic concepts of blockchain, data structures, core technologies and principles, as well as practical applications on Ethereum, such as how to query transactions through Ethereum's Remote Procedure Call (RPC), how to retrieve the balance of a specific address in a particular ERC-20 or ERC-721 token contract, and how to obtain metadata for specific tokens. In addition, this topic will also delve into issues related to blockchain data, such as data immutability, data retrieval efficiency, and data scalability.
Through this topic, students will be able to better grasp the core concepts of blockchain and Ethereum technology, laying a solid foundation for future research and practical applications.

questions.title: What is the main design purpose of blockchain?
Why might nodes on the blockchain be inefficient in data retrieval?
options: Because nodes need to verify each transaction
Because the data is linearly stored, not index-optimized
Because nodes do not support SQL queries
Because nodes use slow storage hardware

questions.title: What is a Merkle tree on the blockchain?
options: A data structure used to record transaction history
A data structure used to verify the integrity of transaction data

questions.title: Which technology can improve the scalability of blockchain?
In blockchain applications, what technology is commonly used to ensure data immutability?
When you want to query multiple related transactions from a blockchain application, what data structure are you most likely to use?
In blockchain-based data analysis applications, what technology can help track fund flows?
To retrieve logs within a specific block range on Ethereum, which RPC method should you use?
If you want to use Ethereum RPC to query the balance of a specific address in a particular ERC-20 token contract, what should you do?
options: Directly use the eth_balanceOf method and provide the address and token contract address.
Use the eth_getBalance method and only provide the address to be queried.
Use the eth_call method to send a call to the ERC-20 contract, including the signature of the balanceOf function and the address to be queried.
Use eth_getTransactionCount and provide the address and token contract address.
